hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Ibn Abbas: The Prophet ﷺ said regarding the martyrs: 'Wrap them in their clothes.' That is, wrap them in them without washing.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abu Hurairah: The Prophet ﷺ said: 'If it were not that I dislike burdening my Ummah, I would have loved not to stay behind from any expedition sent in the way of Allah, but I find no means to carry you, and you find no means to be carried, and it grieves you that you stay behind after me.'

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abu Ubaidah: It reached me from the Prophet ﷺ that he raced the horses that were prepared from al-Hafya', and the extent of their race was Thania al-Wada', and he raced the horses that were not prepared from the Thania to the mosque of Bani Zuraiq. And it has reached me that Abdullah ibn Umar was among those who raced.

narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Yusuf ibn Hukam al-Hadani al-Tammaar
narrators.alternative_names: Abu al-Ala' al-Tammaar, Muhammad ibn Yusuf al-Hadani

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abu Ubaidah: From Jabir ibn Zayd, from Abu Said al-Khudri: Umar ibn al-Khattab may Allah be pleased with him donated a fine horse in the way of Allah, then found it being sold in the market. He asked the Prophet ﷺ about it, and he said: 'Do not buy it back, and do not return in your charity, for the one who returns in his charity is like the dog that returns to its vomit.'

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abu Hurairah: The Prophet ﷺ said: 'Horses are of three types: for a man they are a source of reward, for another a covering, and for another a burden. As for the one for whom they are a source of reward, it is a man who ties them in the way of Allah and gives them long rope in a pasture or garden. Whatever they consume in that pasture or garden is recorded as good deeds for him. Even if the rope breaks and they run up to a hill or two, their footprints and droppings are recorded as good deeds for him. If they pass by a river and drink from it without him intending that, it is recorded as good deeds for him. Such horses are a source of reward. And a man who ties them for self-sufficiency and dignity, but does not forget Allah's right over their necks and backs - such horses are a covering for him. And a man who ties them out of pride and showing off and to demonstrate hostility towards the Muslims - such horses are a burden upon him.' Al-Rabi' explained: 'Giving them long rope' means when he ties them with a rope in a pasture and extends the rope so they can graze. 'They ran up' means they galloped. 'Did not forget Allah's right' means he did not abandon Allah's right. 'Demonstrating hostility towards the Muslims' means enmity towards the Muslims.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Ibn Abbas: The Prophet ﷺ said: 'I have been commanded to fight people until they say there is no god but Allah. When they say this, they have protected from me their blood and their wealth except by its right.' And in another narration: 'Your blood and your wealth are forbidden to you.'

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abu Ubaidah from Jabir ibn Zayd from Aisha may Allah be pleased with her: The Prophet ﷺ said: 'Whoever takes up weapons against us is not from us.' Al-Rabi' said: Abu Ubaidah meant: whoever takes them to the land of the enemy. And from Abi Ayyub al-Ansari, who said: I heard the Prophet ﷺ saying: 'An early morning expedition in the way of Allah or an afternoon expedition is better than all that the sun has risen upon.'

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abu Ubaidah from Jabir: It reached me from Abu Qatadah who said: We went out with the Prophet ﷺ in the year of Hunayn, and when we met (the enemy) the Muslims turned back in retreat. I saw a man from the polytheists overpowering a man from the Muslims. I went around to get behind him and struck him with my sword on the neck vein until I cut through the armor. He then turned toward me and embraced me with such force that I felt the smell of death, then death overtook him and he released me. I then went and heard the Prophet ﷺ saying: 'Whoever kills an enemy and has evidence for it, then the spoils are his.' I stood up and said: Who will testify for me? I sat down. Then the Prophet ﷺ said the same thing again, and I stood up saying: Who will testify for me? Then he said it a third time, and I stood up. The Prophet ﷺ said: 'What is wrong with you, Abu Qatadah?' I related the incident to him. A man from the people said: You are truthful, O Messenger of Allah, and his spoils are with me, so compensate him from it. Abu Bakr al-Siddiq said: No, by Allah! He will not go to one of Allah's lions who fights in the cause of Allah and His Messenger only for you to give him his spoils. The Prophet ﷺ said: 'He is truthful, so give them to him.' Abu Qatadah said: So he gave them to me, and I sold the armor and bought a palm garden (kharraf) in Bani Salamah, and it was the first wealth I acquired in Islam. Al-Rabi' explained: Al-kharraf means a grove of date palms, and I acquired it means I earned it.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abu Ubaidah: I heard from Anas ibn Malik who said: The Prophet ﷺ went out to Khaybar, arriving there at night. He never attacked a people at night until the morning. When morning came, the Jews came out with their pickaxes and baskets. When they saw him, they said: Muhammad, by Allah, and the army. The Prophet ﷺ said: 'Allah is the Greatest. Khaybar is ruined. When we descend in the courtyard of a people, how evil is the morning of the warned ones.' And it is narrated: From Ubadah ibn al-Samit who said: The Prophet ﷺ led us in prayer, and a camel from the spoils passed by us. When he finished, he took a piece of hair from the back of the camel and said: 'What is lawful for me from your spoils weighs only this, except the fifth, and it is returned to you.'

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abu Hurairah: We went out with the Prophet ﷺ in the year of Khaybar, and we did not gain gold or silver, except goods and merchandise. A man from Bani al-Dubaib named Rifa'ah ibn Zayd gifted the Prophet ﷺ a black slave named Midham. The Prophet ﷺ sent him towards Wadi al-Qura. When we were there, as Midham was setting down the Prophet's ﷺ saddles, an arrow struck him and killed him. The people said: Congratulations to him, Paradise is his. But the Prophet ﷺ said: 'No, by the One in Whose Hand my soul is, the sheet he took from the spoils on the day of Khaybar, which was not apportioned to him, will burn upon him with fire.' When the people heard that, a man brought a shoelace or two shoelaces and said to him: The Prophet ﷺ said: 'A shoelace or two shoelaces from the fire.'
